text: Question 2 0 out of 1 points Kate, a 34-year-old female, presents o the Emergency Department concerned that her mouth is drooping on one side. She says that she first noticed it this morning and it has worsened over the last 4 hours. On further questioning she has a feeling of ‘fullness’ in the left ear and she reports “everything sounds loud”. She denies any other neurological symptoms including diplopia, dysphagia, facial numbness, dizziness, paraesthesiae, or limb weakness. She has previously been well and is on no medications apart from the oral contraceptive pill. An ear examination is normal. Selected c. Commence oral acyclovir and prednisolone Answer: Answers: A. Arrange acupuncture B. Commence oral acyclovir c. Commence oral acyclovir and prednisolone D. Commence oral prednisolone . Refer for magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) Answer Antiviral agents such as acyclovir alone are inferior to oral prednisolone. While often prescribed in combination with prednisolone there is only a small potential for benefit, and this may be considered in Feedback: severe cases. There is currently no evidence to support the use of either antiviral drug on its own, and there is uncertainty regarding the benefit of adding them to corticosteroids.
